sentences.text: To put it frankly, he is a critic rather than a writer.
Frankly speaking, it's difficult to understand why you want to go.
Saying what you think frankly is not a bad thing.

definition: To cause to feel fear.

sentences.text: The steam took the most weird shapes, enough to frighten any one.
My personality is so overbearting that it can frighten just about anyone.
His Deſign was only to frighten France, and get more Money.

definition: Afraid.

sentences.text: He was very much frightened at the sight of the big snake.
The primitive man was frightened at the sight of a savage beast.
He was so frightened that he could not speak for a moment.

definition: Causing fear.

sentences.text: In contrast to his frightening looks, his voice was kind and calm.
Tom is a frightening example of how alcohol can destroy a person.
It must have been a frightening sight for them to watch.

definition: Foiled, stopped, disappointed.

sentences.text: Frustrated by the ticket, the driver furiously kicked the parking meter.
Tom is frustrated that his girlfriend hasn't called him back yet.
Tom and Mary told John that they thought Alice was frustrated.

definition: Discouraging.

sentences.text: I find striptease frustrating, as it doesn't often culminate in actual sex.
I've decided to not vote anymore because I find the process frustrating.
It's frustrating to realize I’ve repeated the same mistakes over and over.

definition: The feeling of annoyance at impossibility from resistance or inability to achieve something.

sentences.text: Europeans have vented their frustration over rising prices and shrinking purchasing power.
His Borgesian short stories reflected the frustration of the younger generation.
Gabriel waved his hands in frustration when the truck wouldn't start.

definition: A fried piece of cut potato.

sentences.text: Would you like me to fry you a couple of eggs?
You'll fry if you go out in this sun with no sunblock on.
Why don't you fry up some of those nice sausages for our barbecue?

definition: British standard spelling of fulfill.

sentences.text: Your sighs are in vain - I will not fulfil your fantasy.
However, Tutu was able, in the end, to fulfil her godfather’s wish.
What conditions do you have to fulfil to join this club?

definition: Involving a full amount of time spent on some activity, especially a job.

sentences.text: Tom gave up his teaching job to become a full-time studio musician.
I am working full-time at a bookshop until the end of September.
The referee blew his whistle twice to tell everyone it was full-time.

definition: In a fundamental or basic sense.

sentences.text: U.S. Americans fundamentally misunderstand Canadians, believing them to be weak, soft pushovers.
The situation had fundamentally changed, and all prior plans had to be scrapped.
Fundamentally, the formation of the twelve zodiac signs is related to animal worship.

definition: Feeling great anger.

sentences.text: Tom is furious that Mary is going to Boston without him.
If Mary finds out I told you this, she'll be furious.
This news made Al-Sayib so furious that he once more spilled his Fanta.

definition: A unit of volume, equivalent to eight pints.

sentences.text: The car my grandfather gave me only got ten miles per gallon.
The car my grandfather gave me only got ten miles to the gallon.
A spoonful of honey will catch more flies than a gallon of vinegar.

definition: A fixed look.

sentences.text: I kept gazing at her until she, totally confused, dropped her gaze.
Don't look into the abyss. Otherwise, the abyss will gaze into you.
She had a deep gaze and beautiful amber brown colored eyes.

definition: The systematic killing of substantial numbers of people on other grounds.

sentences.text: English linguistic imperialism is a genocide against the languages of the world.
European surnames among Ashkenazi Jews are a result of cultural genocide.
The Nazi genocide of Roma and Sinti is called the Porajmos.

definition: In a genuine manner.

sentences.text: I recommend this movie to all and sundry. It is genuinely interesting.
That's a very harmful thing to genuinely believe, let alone live by.
The students were genuinely interested in the guest speaker's inspiring life story.

definition: A motion of the limbs or body, especially one made to emphasize speech.

sentences.text: Without shaking, she poured water in the glass with an elegant gesture.
The airline provided free accommodation to stranded passengers as a goodwill gesture.
The acceptability of a social gesture depends on innumerable cultural factors.

definition: To see or view someone, or something tangible briefly and incompletely.

sentences.text: We had a glimpse of the lake as we flew over it.
I have only begun to glimpse the magnitude of the problem.
I had a glimpse into the negative side of his character.

definition: American and Oxford British English standard spelling of globalisation.

sentences.text: Globalization doesn't just take place in the economy, but also in culture.
I think that globalization has negative effects as well as positive.
The finance minister said that Bangladesh has utilized the opportunity of globalization well.

definition: Exhibiting attributes, qualities, or acts that are worthy of or receive glory.

sentences.text: With one glorious right hook, Punkin' Pie uncrowned the reigning heavyweight champion.
Peace is a meaningless word; what is needed is a glorious peace.
From the terrace, there was a glorious view of Mont Blanc.

definition: An thing of clothing.

sentences.text: Tom folded the map and put it back into the glove compartment.
Dan never handles his big hairy spider without a thick glove.
I lost a glove. Now what should I do with the second one?

definition: The state or characteristic of being good.

sentences.text: Rich, raisiny, smoky, coffee goodness: that is the flavor of urfa biber.
He had the goodness to come all the way to see me.
Thank goodness it didn't worsen. But please don't push yourself yet.

definition: To make and administer the public policy and affairs of.

sentences.text: Which is the best government? That which teaches us to govern ourselves.
He that would govern others, first should be master of himself.
The West wants to govern the globe and steal its resources.

definition: To grip.

sentences.text: Some people find it easier to grasp the short-term effects of smoking.
We couldn't grasp the meaning of what he was trying to say.
Tom has a good grasp of grammar, but is weak in spelling.

definition: To weep.

sentences.text: He was aware of my presence but he did not greet me.
When the visitor entered the room, we stood to greet him.
I didn't greet you because I mistook you for somebody else.

definition: Emotional pain.

sentences.text: She was filled with grief at the news of her sister's death.
Grief on the face is better than the stain in the heart.
The neighbour's teenagers give me grief every time they see me.

definition: To smile, parting the lips so as to show the teeth.

sentences.text: Matthew came running into the kitchen with a huge grin on his face.
Tom had no choice but to grin and bear it.
"What an idyllic picture," he said with a wry grin.

definition: To reduce to smaller pieces by crushing with lateral motion.

sentences.text: I've been on the grind all week, trying to make ends meet.
Ancient Greeks built water wheels to grind grain thousands of years ago.
The mills of the gods grind slowly, but they grind exceedingly fine.

definition: A soldier in a small independent group.

sentences.text: In reports in America, guerrilla resistance by the Iraq military is called terrorism.
It's not "gorilla rain", but "guerrilla rain"; do you understand?
Guerrilla gardening is gardening on another person's land without permission.

definition: A non-specific rule or principle that provides direction to action or behaviour.

sentences.text: He considered the Ten Commandments more as a guideline than a requirement.
Rules are made for fools to follow and for wise men to use as a guideline.
The results can guideline over time despite strict controls.

definition: Responsibility for wrongdoing.

sentences.text: The police had to retrieve the murder weapon to prove Dan's guilt.
"That's clear evidence of guilt," said Tom. "Not necessarily," replied Maria.
Sociopaths rarely display remorse or feelings of guilt for their crimes.

definition: The alimentary canal, especially the intestine.

sentences.text: You've developed quite a beer gut since I last met you.
Years of heavy drinking has left John with a beer gut.
I have a gut feeling that Tom won't pass the test.

definition: An action performed on a regular basis.

sentences.text: Beth has a strong habit of interrupting people while they are talking.
You should try to form the habit of using your dictionaries.
It is not easy to get rid of a bad habit.

definition: To have hailstones fall from the sky.

sentences.text: The mafia boss was killed in a hail of machine gun fire.
It's neither raining nor snowing today, but there is some light hail.
Dying because of... hail? Now that's a miscalculation and a half.

definition: Half of the way between two points.

sentences.text: Halfway through the second chapter I realized I hadn't taken anything in.
I'm sure you'll be sorry if you give it up halfway through.
It's very rude to run off on somebody halfway through a date.

definition: To limp.

sentences.text: They were unanimous that the war should be brought to a halt.
At the ethics committee, a temporary halt to cloning experiments was decided.
Sami's car came to a screeching halt in front of Layla's house.

definition: The amount that a hand will grasp or contain.

sentences.text: Think of your opponent as nothing more than a handful of ash.
Knap the tongs together about a handful from the bottom.
This handful of men were tied to very hard duty.

definition: In a happy or cheerful manner.

sentences.text: I gave my son a box of candy, which he opened happily.
I'd rather live happily in the present than go down in history.
They married, had a family and lived happily all their lives.

definition: Unpleasantly rough to the touch or other senses.

sentences.text: "Does Dr. Watson live here?" asked a clear but rather harsh voice.
I stepped outside and was bathed in the harsh, direct sunlight.
You don't have to use such a harsh tone with me.

definition: A strong aversion.

sentences.text: They are unanimous in their hate for me—and I welcome their hatred.
The bold man glanced at the gangster with hatred and contempt.
From that moment on, he felt undying hatred for his oppressors.

definition: To inhabit or to visit frequently most often used in reference to ghosts.

sentences.text: If I die today, I'll haunt you every minute of your life.
It shall be the haunt of jackals, an abode for ostriches.
Tell me who you haunt, I'll tell you who you are.

definition: A pain or ache in the head.

sentences.text: So annoying... Now I get a headache whenever I use the computer!
I had a bad headache. That's why I went to bed early.
Getting rid of garbage has become a major headache for the authorities.

definition: To make better from a disease, wound, etc.

sentences.text: He sustained an injury which will take a month to heal completely.
A belly button piercing could take more than six months to heal.
A sprain like this should heal within a week or so.

definition: To make high.

sentences.text: Humanitarian organizations fear the ongoing impasse and the hostile rhetoric could heighten local xenophobia.
They decided to heighten the plan after the review.
The committee will heighten the policy before next week.

definition: That or those belonging to her.

sentences.text: I will see my friends tonight, but my sister won't see hers.
I would give up my own life if it would save hers.
Mine is the blue one, and hers is the red one.

definition: To stop or pause respecting decision or action.

sentences.text: If you should have any trouble, don't hesitate to come to me.
He did not hesitate in taking his share of the money.
He was so hungry that he didn't hesitate to eat everything on the plate.

definition: Important or well publicized.

sentences.text: One high-profile example of an airworthiness directive is the one issued for the Boeing 737 MAX.
The high-profile response calmed the anxious crowd during the hearing.
Her explanation was high-profile and easy for everyone to follow.

definition: Very funny.

sentences.text: The laser cow in WHAT THE CAR? is both hilarious and terrifying!
Susan thought the film was hilarious, but one time was enough.
Ziri's story was hilarious although he didn't mean it to be.

definition: A writer of history.

sentences.text: The art historian wrote an essay about the ancient Greek vase.
Israeli historian Ilan Pappe's books are regarded as solid academic works.
There will be an art historian coming tomorrow to look at the painting.

definition: The act, quality, or condition of being honest.

sentences.text: I have often heard it said that honesty is the best policy.
Honesty does not always pay. Such is the way of the world.
There are none of us who do not respect his honesty.

definition: British, Canadian, Commonwealth, and Ireland standard spelling of honor.

sentences.text: Being given the captaincy was the greatest honour she'd ever been given.
A prophet is not without honour, save in his own country.
It's a shame that you don't honour us with your presence.

definition: A person who is hoping for success or victory.

sentences.text: It looks hopeful that my father will be able to walk again.
She is hopeful the upcoming semester will mark a return to normal.
The hopeful expression with which he looked at her clutched her heart.

definition: A person given as a pledge or security for the performance of the conditions.

sentences.text: Tom brutally killed a hostage who tried to sound the alarm system.
He tried to brave it out while held as a hostage.
He tried to be brave while he was being held hostage.

definition: Not friendly.

sentences.text: The baby is not old enough to be capable of hostile laughter.
This submarine can operate in the most hostile conditions on the planet.
I met with a cool, not to say hostile, reception.

definition: The state of being hostile.

sentences.text: My resentment and anger towards you caused hostility and a division between us.
The burning of the Quran fosters an environment of hostility and religious intolerance.
Analysts sense a growing hostility between the two countries.

definition: To defeat or reduce the power, independence, or pride of.

sentences.text: Despite his achievements, he is very humble and doesn't boast about them.
I particularly noticed one young woman of humble dress, but interesting demeanor.
No matter how humble it is, there's no place like home.

definition: Full of humor or arousing laughter.

sentences.text: "She's not only beautiful but also humorous." "Can she cook?" "Who cares?"
Give me a humorous anecdote so I can have a good laugh.
She gave me a humorous account of her encounter with him.

definition: The quality of being amusing, comical, funny.

sentences.text: "The Nightingale Samurai" is a samurai tale full of humanity and humour.
Humour has justly been regarded as the finest perfection of poetic genius.
A day without a vein of humour is an extremely sad day.

definition: To do things quickly.

sentences.text: Hurry up, or you will be late for the last train.
There is no hurry; you have five days to think the matter over.
If you don't hurry (up) you won't finish on time.

definition: Irrational.

sentences.text: Only people with ideological motives deny the existence of the Berber language.
She did not agree with the ideological aims of the group.
Doping is not compatible with my ideological views on the sport.

definition: Doctrine, philosophy, body of beliefs or principles belonging to an person or group.

sentences.text: We came to the conclusion that the ideology was behind the times.
My ideology does not allow me to consider that a viable option.
Linguistics is science. Racism is ideology. Science and ideology don't go together.

definition: A person of low general intelligence.

sentences.text: After failing a hat-trick of exams, the teacher called him an idiot.
Yes, in Osaka, too, we say "idiot" when we are insulting someone.
I walk in the rain like an idiot and you're not there.

definition: The condition of being uninformed or uneducated.

sentences.text: Some speculators take advantage of the ignorance and helplessness of old people.
True science teaches us to doubt and to abstain from ignorance.
The more a man knows, the more he discovers his ignorance.

definition: Anything that seems to be something that it is not.

sentences.text: He has the illusion that he is the smartest in his class.
Absolute privacy on Facebook is an illusion. It doesn't exist in reality.
An optical illusion makes the second object look larger than the first.

definition: To clarify something by giving, or serving as, an example or a comparison.

sentences.text: I will give you a good example to illustrate what I mean.
This dictionary has sentences that illustrate how to use each word.
We illustrate our definitions by including quotations or simple examples.

definition: The work of one who makes images or visible representation of objects.

sentences.text: The poem relies heavily on imagery associated with night.
Govind's company creates computer-generated imagery for blockbuster films.
The careful use of evocative imagery is an important part of building a successful advertising campaign.

definition: Existing only in the imagination.

sentences.text: You say Nessie is an imaginary being, but I think she exists.
Specular image holds an important place in Lakan's theory of the Imaginary.
Gondal is an imaginary world created by Emily and Anne Brontë.

definition: Huge, gigantic, very large.

sentences.text: Every chord, every harmony, every discordant note fills me with immense joy.
Chess is like an immense ocean. Checkers is like a deep well.
An immense monument was erected in honor of the eminent philosopher.

definition: A non-native person who comes to a country from another country to permanently settle.

sentences.text: Sami first came to Canada 36 years ago as an Egyptian immigrant.
Joe Arpaio was bullied as a child for having Italian immigrant parents.
Oliver found out that his new girlfriend is an illegal immigrant.

definition: About to happen.

sentences.text: If not for the ozone layer, we would be in imminent danger.
The dark clouds and swirling wind indicated that a storm was imminent.
According to the radio, a storm is imminent in the North Sea.

definition: Restless, short of temper, and intolerant of delays.

sentences.text: What, will you tear / Impatient answers from my gentle tongue?
Impatient at the delay, many drivers began to blow their horns.
An impatient driver forced his way through the crossing against the red light.

definition: The act of implicating.

sentences.text: The implication was that where there was a well, there were residents.
Algeria is facing the economic implication of the coronavirus.
I resent your implication that I am engaged to you only because of your money.

definition: To have as a necessary consequence.

sentences.text: We didn't mean to imply that Mary wasn't good enough for Tom.
He would always imply that what others are saying isn't valid.
I didn't mean to imply the work you're doing isn't worthwhile.

definition: To affect someone strongly and often favourably.

sentences.text: Okay, so you're a rocket scientist / That don't impress me much
The United States tries to impress the world with its weapons.
I bet you think I'm just writing that to impress you.

definition: To put in or as if in prison.

sentences.text: The target of both armies is to imprison the opponent's king.
If they find out where Ziri is, they'll imprison him again.
Today, a nation ringed by walls would only imprison itself.

definition: A confinement in a place.

sentences.text: Human rights organisations say many experience imprisonment and beatings along the way.
The joy was indescribably great when Tom was released from political imprisonment.
Having been convicted of murder, he was sentenced to life imprisonment.

definition: Lack of the ability to do something.

sentences.text: One of Tom's greatest failings is his seeming inability to admit defeat.
Your inability to accept constructive criticism reveals your delusion of being faultless.
Inability to disprove a theory does not mean it is right.

definition: Not adequate.

sentences.text: The road is inadequate for the amount of traffic which it carries.
The dogmas of the quiet past, are inadequate to the stormy present.
Iran's mining sector faces various challenges, including inadequate infrastructure and outdated technology.

definition: At an angle to the horizontal.

sentences.text: Scarcely had I heard the news when I felt inclined to cry.
Tom is inclined to be moody and isn't easy to live with.
I am inclined now to have a little amusement at his expense.

definition: In an incredible manner.

sentences.text: Beth protested, but her mother reminded her that she was incredibly fat.
Of course I know who he is! He's an incredibly smart boy.
We were incredibly intelligent about some of the hazards that we faced.

definition: To bring upon oneself or expose oneself to, especially something inconvenient, harmful, or onerous.

sentences.text: You do not want to incur the wrath of God.
If you are not careful, you will incur prohibitive expenses.
[T]he master in his wrath may easily incur worse evil himself than he inflicts—[...]

definition: An official formal accusation for a criminal offence.

sentences.text: It is unlikely that this indictment will lead to his deportation.
The family name fell into disrepute following their son's federal indictment.
The indictment was central to the team's discussion today.

definition: The interior of a building.

sentences.text: Since it was raining, we had to eat our picnic lunch indoors.
The best bet on a rainy day is to remain indoors.
It rained heavily all day, during which time I stayed indoors.

definition: To lead by persuasion or influence.

sentences.text: Because of the increasing risk of complications the doctor decided to induce labor.
Tom is involved in a top-secret project which weaponizes high-frequency sounds to induce amnesia.
They induce uncertainty in muscle power, confusion in mind power, and imbecility in soul power.

definition: To yield to a temptation or desire.

sentences.text: Thus you cannot indulge in the pleasure of spending money freely.
You shouldn't indulge that child. It will make him very selfish.
He began to indulge in drinking after he lost his wife.

definition: Absence of equality.

sentences.text: Men's tendency to devalue anything feminine reinforces gender inequality and hampers progress.
No inequality should be allowed to exist between men and women.
Algeria does not have inequality like a nation like South Africa.

definition: Something that is predictable, necessary, or cannot be avoided.

sentences.text: Overtaxed heart, kidneys and liver are inevitable results of too much food.
As people are still generally insufficiently educated, wars are still inevitable.
There isn't anything that anybody can do to avoid the inevitable.

definition: In a manner that is impossible to avoid or prevent.

sentences.text: Every time I get really tired, I inevitably have a senior moment.
Whoever reads this so-called newspaper every day will inevitably go daft.
If a noise was unidentified, Tom's dog inevitably barked at it.

definition: Having a bad reputation.

sentences.text: The most infamous expression for the year 2011 is "Kebab murders".
While in jail, Tom made the acquaintance of John, an infamous bank robber.
Facebook is infamous for helping to usher in the era of "fake news".

definition: To contaminate an thing or substance with a pathogen.

sentences.text: You're not going to infect me with an illness that doesn't exist.
Making matters worse, schools often sent the sickest children home to infect families and communities.
The virus can easily infect a healthy person.

definition: To introduce something as a reasoned result.

sentences.text: This doth infer the zeal I had to see him.
I can infer that something went wrong here, even if I don't know what.
What do you infer from her strange behavior?

definition: To thrust upon.

sentences.text: You should not inflict any injury on others on any account.
Sociopaths never feel remorse and they rationalize the pain they inflict on others.
Words can inflict wounds that are harder to heal than those from weapons.

definition: A person who has influence.

sentences.text: Rousseau was mad but influential; Hume was sane but had no followers.
Tom doesn't seem to be as influential as Mary seems to be.
He is a prestigious and influential member of the Democratic Party.

definition: One of the substances present in a mixture, especially food.

sentences.text: Water is the chief ingredient in all the animal fluids and solids.
Tom peeped over Mary's shoulder to see what the secret ingredient was.
Eggplant is the main ingredient of some vegetarian dishes with tomato sauce.

definition: Someone or thing who lives in a place.

sentences.text: Sami is the only inhabitant of the island.
The inhabitant response calmed the anxious crowd during the hearing.
Her explanation was inhabitant and easy for everyone to follow.

definition: Naturally as part or consequence of something.

sentences.text: There's a deception inherent to any politician's claim to represent a constituency.
We must never forget the inherent value of every human being.
The Diaoyu Islands have long been an inherent territory of China.

definition: To receive property.

sentences.text: Tom stands to inherit a lot of money when his parents die.
With his wife dead, Dan stood to inherit half a million dollars.
Tom certainly didn't expect to inherit the house from his uncle.

definition: To hold in or hold back.

sentences.text: He noticed that this drug seemed to inhibit bacterial growth.
Yet education is the only factor that can inhibit prejudice, be it between ethnicities or genders.
It’s believed purple nut sedge may have the ability to inhibit the growth of Streptococcus mutans.

definition: To begin.

sentences.text: You shouldn't wait for changes to come – you should initiate them yourself.
"I'll do my best" often means "I won't initiate anything".
Politicians initiate wars, not ordinary people who suffer from them.

definition: To push or pump something, especially fluids into a cavity or passage.

sentences.text: I have to use a needle to inject this under your skin.
She was trying to inject some fun into the grim proceedings.
Yanni needs this syringe to inject resin into his windshield crack.

definition: To wound or cause physical harm to a living creature.

sentences.text: What should I do if I injure myself with a used needle?
You may injure yourselves if you don't follow the safety procedures.
You have to be careful so as not to injure yourself.

definition: Absence of justice.

sentences.text: Woman as I am, I shall stand up against any social injustice.
Mary's father complains about the injustice of the capitalist social system.
Giving a scholarship to that ignorant, shiftless student is an injustice.

definition: A person confined to an institution such as a prison as a convict or hospital.

sentences.text: Dan asked fellow inmate Matt to supply him with a fork.
Ziri's relationship with Mina blurred the lines between guard and inmate.
The guard punished an inmate in front of the newcomers.

definition: An arthropod in the Insecta class characterized by six legs.

sentences.text: Thanks to this book, I learned some interesting facts about this insect.
The body of an insect is divided into head, thorax and abdomen.
Tom drove to the store and bought three cans of insect spray.

definition: To hold up a claim emphatically.

sentences.text: There are a lot of people who always insist on the right.
You must not insist on going out alone so late at night.
Angles likewise which insist on the Diameter, are all Right Angles.

definition: To examine critically or carefully.

sentences.text: He will come here soon to inspect the industry of this town.
What exactly am I supposed to inspect? Are they just random things?
Inspect your tires for wear and tear, and replace them if necessary.

definition: To draw in by the operation of breathing.

sentences.text: How can video games inspire us to make better applications for e-learning?
The head of the government must inspire the faith of the people.
Lovell hopes his story and experiences inspire a new generation of explorers.

definition: A natural or inherent impulse or behaviour.

sentences.text: In making a decision, I rely not on logic but on instinct.
Nature never appeals to intelligence until habit and instinct are useless.
Social networks enable men to revive their instinct of pack hunters, like hyena.

definition: To teach by giving instructions.

sentences.text: Usage note: "instruct" is less forceful than "order", but weightier than "advise"
If you're not careful, I'm going to instruct a solicitor over this.
A multitude of books burdens the student, does not instruct him.

definition: Not enough.

sentences.text: Don't read under insufficient light, for it is bad for your eyes.
Life is the art of drawing sufficient conclusions from insufficient premises.
The district attorney is unwilling to proceed due to insufficient evidence.

definition: Action or form of speech deliberately intended to be rude.

sentences.text: The way the orchestra performed tonight was an insult to my ears.
Tom considered it an insult not to be invited to the party.
It was apprehended not as a gratitude but as an insult.

definition: Left complete or whole.

sentences.text: Even though the car accident damaged his body, his optimism was intact.
To keep their power structures intact, corrupt politicians often rail against leftists.
The TV set is intact even though it fell off the desk.

definition: To render more intense.

sentences.text: Continuing to eat while I talk will only intensify my disapproval.
The feelings of discomfort intensify every time I see you.
The argument between Tom and Mary began to intensify.

definition: To get involved or involve oneself, causing disturbance.

sentences.text: I always try not to interfere with other people’s personal affairs.
Don't interfere with him if you want him to like you.
Correlated waves interfere to produce interesting patterns, while uncorrelated waves overlap without interfering.

definition: To explain or tell the meaning of.

sentences.text: I don't want Tom to think he has to interpret for me.
People with low self-esteem tend to interpret everything in a negative way.
I decided to interpret your remark in the most literal way possible.

definition: To disturb or halt an ongoing process or action.

sentences.text: There are people who just want to interrupt and waste your time.
It is not polite to interrupt someone while he is talking.
You should not interrupt when someone is talking to someone else.

definition: To occur or act as an obstacle or delay.

sentences.text: The kids fought with each other, so the parents had to intervene.
The police had to be called to intervene in the fight.
They should not intervene in the internal affairs of another country.

definition: Causing a desire to know more.

sentences.text: The thought of being eaten alive was both frightening and intriguing.
The concept of family is both foreign and intriguing to me.
I believe I've found something intriguing that you'll want to see.

definition: To move into.

sentences.text: The Germans planned to destroy the Royal Air Force and invade Britain.
Under some circumstances police are allowed to invade a person's privacy.
It should be forbidden to invade countries whose names one can't pronounce correctly.

definition: To design a new process or mechanism.

sentences.text: If God did not exist, it would be necessary to invent him.
Someone please invent a mescal tequila and habanero cocktail called “Tire Fire”.
I just said what I have seen, I did not invent anything.

definition: To call upon a person, a god for help, assistance or guidance.

sentences.text: In pots I try in vain to invoke the scents of childhood.
Once Tom tried to invoke a demon, and he almost succeeded.
Could the US invoke NATO's Article 5 to attack North Korea?

definition: Characterized by or constituting any kind of irony.

sentences.text: It's ironic that we are eating a sandwich in Sandwich, Massachusetts.
When people use the word "ironic", they may mean "comically incongruous".
It's somewhat ironic to have a wave of smog right on Earth Day.

definition: In an ironic manner.

sentences.text: Ironically, the remix ended up several times more popular than the original song.

Now came shipwrecks and life in open boats, with the usual paucity of food.

definition: Insolent and shameless audacity.

sentences.text: His effrontery has turned everyone in the firm against him.
His effrontery turned everyone in the firm against him.
The effrontery was central to the team's discussion today.

definition: The termination of an organized body or legislative assembly, especially a formal dismissal.

sentences.text: He led a life of dissolution, drinking and gambling almost daily.
Justice without mercy is cruelty; mercy without justice is the mother of dissolution.
Tom and Mary announced the dissolution of their marriage.

definition: Having many overlapping coils or folds.

sentences.text: Tom's speech was convoluted and disjointed and was very hard to follow.
The plot's so convoluted, I have no idea what's going on.
I seek clarity, but the more I think, the more convoluted everything appears.

definition: Adhering only to principles which are true a priori.

sentences.text: It's profound ignorance that inspires the dogmatic tone of speaking.
Tom's father is very dogmatic and rigid in his views.
Profound ignorance is what is behind a dogmatic tone.

definition: Extreme poverty or destitution.

sentences.text: The indigence was central to the team's discussion today.
Their indigence shaped how the project moved forward this week.
Our indigence for the project required careful planning.

definition: Tending to prohibit, preclude, or disallow.

sentences.text: I must admit that lately living in the city has become almost prohibitive.
If you are not careful, you will incur prohibitive expenses.
The cost of entry to some gigs is prohibitive.

definition: Selecting a mixture of what appears to be best of various doctrines, methods or styles.

sentences.text: Her eclectic taste was evident from the unusual decor of the room.
Though rooted in jazz, Byron's music is stylistically eclectic.
The eclectic on the panel drew ideas from many traditions.
